Tz'u-chou type ware
Stoneware with black glaze and russet splashes markings
title: Pear-shaped Bottle
text:
Used for storing wine during the Chin (1115-1234) and Yuan (1280-1368) dynasties, pear-shaped bottles of this type are usually called either ping (bottles) or chang ching ping (long-necked bottles) by the Chinese. The form originated in silver vessels and was quickly imitated in ceramic Ting ware during the eleventh century.

The dark-brown, almost black glaze is applied over a layer of white slip, a technique common to the Tz'u-chou and Tz'u-chou type kilns of Honan province. The surface is further enhanced with thick, silvery russet iron-oxide glaze with two bands of five alternating abstracted leaf-shaped splashes. Tz'u-chou kilns are best known for the production of brown and white decorated ware, but they were very competitive and imitated black and brown wares that were popularized by other kilns in different regions of China.
description: round body on ring foot with tall thin neck and flaring lip; dark brown glaze with light brown teardrop-shaped brushstrokes
